annotation.TEXT: That's...not how this part is usually supposed to be done, but hey, I'll take it (especially considering this spot is super tight if you manage to land these jumps on the first cycle, and even if you do land them, there's a decent chance you'll hit your head on the spiked ceiling and die instantly).

Next up is Gaibon, and what better way to begin the fight than with bad timing on my part? For reference, you can actually land a bunch of hits on Gaibon right away if you use similar cross throws to the ones here (as mentioned however, I just timed it badly). Beyond that, there's not much else to say on Gaibon himself. He's the the most straight-forward of the final bosses in terms of pattern and attacks.

As for Death, the fight with him isn't quite as bad as you might suspect. He still has those mini-scythes, but now he throws them directly at you, making them easier to predict and destroy in the process. This works out really well if you keep your distance, seeing as the mini-scythes actually have a limited range on them.

Anyways, welcome to the lair of the 3 fiends (and Dracula). Starting off this boss rush of sorts, we have Slogra. I have no idea how other people view this fight, but I honestly consider him to be the toughest boss in the game. My main reasoning behind this? Aside from Simon himself, Slogra is the ONLY other thing in this entire game that gains significant invincibility frames after being hit. This turns his otherwise simple-looking routine into a very grueling battle.

Final phase: Dracula will use a new attack that rains purple lightning down in set locations. The lightning itself deals a sizable amount of damage, but it's not that difficult to avoid (even though I do get hit by it a few times...by this point, Dracula didn't have much of a chance anyways).

Here's where the real danger starts to kick in. That spiked wheel will slowly make its way up the screen and eventually catch you if you're not fast enough (for reference, touching it causes instant death). Adding onto this is the fact that all the stairs in this area will begin falling apart once you attempt to climb them. Speaking of which, the game also really wants to make sure you've learned how to jump onto the stairs (as some spots require this for you to move on).

The general rule of thumb always seems to decree that the Clock Tower is the worst level in any given Castlevania game. I personally don't think this place is as bad as Stage 8, but it still has its moments, especially when it comes to the enemies (there's one in particular here that I consider to be the worst enemy in the whole game, which is entirely due to its placement).

His first phase is actually pretty easy, and you can get him into a loop by ducking and attacking him once his invincibility wears off (as shown here). After losing half his health however, things start to get nasty. During his second phase, his main attack is replaced with a forwards lunge. This is incredibly dangerous not only due to how much damage it does, but also because it's nearly impossible to outrun this move if Slogra decides to use it the moment he lands back on the ground (which he can and will do if you're unlucky).

On one final note...does anyone out there actually know what Slogra is even supposed to be? I always thought he was some kind of prehistoric bird skeleton, but apparently there's a few different theories as to what he is.

The skeleton knight that appears after the ring segment up ahead is that "one enemy" I was referring to earlier. How badly the situation with it goes is all dependent on how you swing on the rings: If you swing too far, you'll scroll the skeleton knight on-screen at the end of the platform too early, which will most likely cause him to walk forward and immediately shove you off the edge.

The only reason I used the secret here was to refill my health a bit and get a few hearts in the process. I didn't go for the maximum amount (99), since you really don't need that many to beat Dracula. Hell, even 50 hearts is a bit overkill for this.

The purple orb is another attack that he can bust out during either his first or second phases. Hitting it causes it to spray projectiles in all directions...but it does next to no damage, and it actually spawns some health for you once it's finished.

For the second phase, he'll summon two pillars of fire that form into masks that home in on you. They can be a bit annoying to deal with depending on where they spawn and even where you attack them (since doing so causes them to fall to the floor, which in turn kicks up a small fire that can damage you). Thankfully, Dracula can only have two fire masks on-screen at the same time.
As a side note: I've never been good at dealing with the fire masks. Then again...Dracula makes up for it by giving out free health from time to time. >_>

Aside from his diving attack, he also has one other new trick: attempting to pull you towards him while his larger scythe tries to fly into you. It's worth noting that you can't use sub-weapons on him while he's doing this attack (there seems to be a set zone where Death's wind effect takes place, and any sub-weapon that comes in contact with it immediately dissolves).

Dracula's fight is broken up into different phases of three distinct attacks. The first of these is a small purple fireball he shoots from his cape. Hitting this causes it to split into three, though it becomes easier to jump over once it splits. Then again, why shouldn't you just jump over it in the first place? Because doing so actually causes the projectile to split upwards, effectively turning it into an anti-air move that immediately counters your jump.

I always found it odd how the giant bouncing gears aren't more prevalent in the rest of the level. There's only 3 in total, and they only show up for this particular section. Granted, they can lead to some jarring situations if you don't notice them right away, but if handled correctly, I think they could serve as a decent reoccurring hazard for this stage.

Well, here we go. "Stage B" is generally considered the most diabolical level in the entire game (primarily due to its second half). The first portion of it isn't too bad, though it also clues you in on the fact that this level has a really big fascination with crumbling/falling structures.
